question: Se abbod grete þone (cyning) #### — The abbot greets the king
explanation: Here 'cyning' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'gretan', so is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: Se þegen sloh þone (biscop) #### in þæm tune — The thane slew the bishop in the town
explanation: Here 'biscop' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'sloh', so is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: Ða biscopas geafon þone (stan) #### to þæm þegne — The bishops gave the stone to the thane
explanation: Here 'stan' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: Se cyning ond seo cwen gretaþ þa (biscop) #### — The king and the queen greet the bishops
explanation: Here 'biscop' is plural and directly receiving the action of the verb 'grete', so it takes the plural accusative 'as' ending to become 'biscopas'

question: Se cyning sloh þa (þegen) #### — The king slew the thanes
explanation: Here 'þegen' is plural and directly receiving the action of the verb 'sloh', so it takes the plural accusative 'as' ending to become 'þegnas'

question: Se þegen geaf þa (gar) #### to þaem cyninge — The thane gives the spears to the king
explanation: Here 'gar' is plural and directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it takes the plural accusative 'as' ending to become 'garas'

question: To þæm biscope geaf se cyning þa (beag) #### — The king gave rings to the bishop
explanation: Here 'beag' is plural and directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it takes the plural accusative 'as' ending to become 'beagas'

question: To þæm (cyning) #### geaf se biscop beag — To the king, the bishop gave a ring
explanation: Here 'cyning' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending to become 'cyninge'

commonMistakes.explanation: Cyning is the nominative or accusative singular form of the word. Here 'cyning' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending to become 'cyninge'

question: Se þegen ferþ to þæm (biscop) #### mid þæs cyninges wordum — The thane goes to the bishop with words from the king
explanation: Here 'biscop' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferþ', so it takes the singular dative 'e' ending to become 'biscope'

commonMistakes.explanation: Biscop is the nominative or accusative singular form of the word. Here 'biscop' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending.

question: Se biscop ferde fram þæm (þegen) #### to þæm cyninge — The bishop went from the thane to the king
explanation: Here 'þegen' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferde', so it takes the singular dative 'e' ending to become 'þegne'

question: On þis daege, Æðelred cyning ferde to þæm (tun) #### mid his broðrum — On this day, King Ethelred went to the town with his brothers
explanation: Here 'tun' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferde', so it takes the singular dative 'e' ending to become 'tune'

question: Se cyning ferþ to þæm (beorg) #### — The king goes to the mountains
explanation: Here 'beorg' is plural and not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferþ', so it takes the plural dative 'um' ending to become 'beorgum'

question: Wærferhþ biscop ferde to þæm (biscop) #### in Lundene ond Wiltunscire — Bishop Warfehth went to the bishops of London and Wiltshire
explanation: Here 'biscop' is plural and not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferde', so it takes the plural dative 'um' ending to become 'biscopum'

question: He geaf þa garas to þæm (þegen) #### — He gave the spears to the thanes
explanation: Here 'þegen' is plural and not directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it takes the plural dative 'um' ending to become 'þegnum'

question: Se abbot com fram þæm (beorg) ####⁠ — The abbot came from the mountains
explanation: Here 'beorg' is plural and not directly receiving the action of the verb 'com', so it takes the plural dative 'um' ending to become 'beorgum'

question: Se biscop ferþ to þæm haligan (stede) ####⁠ — The bishop goes to the holy place
explanation: Here 'stede' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferþ', so it should take the singular dative 'e', but since it already ends in 'e' no additional letters are added

commonMistakes.explanation: While 'stede' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferþ' and so is dative singular, it already ends in e, so no additional letters are added

question: Hie þreowon þa (gar) #### to þæm wicingum⁠ — They threw the spears at the vikings
explanation: Here 'gar' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'þreowon', so it takes the plural accusative 'as' ending to become 'garas'

question: He æt þone (fugol) ####⁠ — He ate the bird
explanation: Here 'fugol' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'æt', so it is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: Ða biscopas comon fram þæm (tun) #### Londenum ond Readingum genemned — The bishops came from the towns called London and Reading
explanation: Here 'tun' is plural and not directly receiving the action of the verb 'comon', so takes the plural dative 'um' ending to become 'tunum'
